Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2012 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. These fellowships support a research and training plan at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines. The title of the research fellowship awarded to Ameerah N. Chowdhury is "Shadows and Intersections." The host institution for the fellowship is University of California, Los Angeles, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Benjamin Sudakov.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the highlights of this project was proving the 25-year-old Manickam-Miklos-Singhi conjecture for vector spaces and making substantial progress on the now 29-year-old Manickam-Miklos-Singhi conjecture. This research was shared with the mathematical community in many talks and made publicly available in two publications.

  •  A. Chowdhury, G. Sarkis, and S. Shahriari, The Manickam-Miklos-Singhi Conjectures for Sets and Vector Spaces, J. Combin Theory Ser. A, 128:84-103, 2014.
  • A. Chowdhury, A Note on the Manickam-Miklos-Singhi Conjecture, European J. Combin., 35:131-140, 2014.

The PI also made progress on the 62-year-old MDS conjecture, and this research was shared with the mathematical community in talks and published in an open-access journal.

  • A. Chowdhury, Inclusion Matrices and the MDS Conjecture, Electr. J. Combin. 23(4) (2016), #P4.29

The PI shared knowledge through teaching classes at University of California, Los Angeles and at Rutgers University. At University of California, Los Angeles, the PI taught Math 3C, Probability for Life Sciences during the 2012-2013 academic year.  At Rutgers University, the PI taught Math 350, Linear Algebra, and Math 356, Theory of Numbers, during the 2015-2016 academic year.

The PI promoted diversity in mathematics by supervising a DIMACS REU by Marielle Jurist in the summer of 2016 titled "Bilu-Linial Conjecture and Ramanujan Graphs."
